Israel is in a rare position: Strong and isolated
subhead: While two years of war have left Israel in a position of military dominance, the country's image has collapsed as never before among its friends and traditional allies, writes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

Trump critic and former national security advisor John Bolton indicted
subhead: 'I think he's a bad guy,' Trump told reporters on Thursday about Bolton after the news broke. Bolton's indictment follows the recent pressing of criminal charges by the Trump Justice Department against two other prominent critics of the Republican president – New York Attorney General Letitia James and former FBI director James Comey.

title: In South Korea, digital detox centers are tackling the country's growing tech addiction
subhead: Seoul has made advanced technology a pillar of its economic development, but the nation's youth are consequently facing high exposure to digital addiction. The issue is so acute that the government funds programs to treat dependency on smartphones and online gaming.

title: Ace Frehley, founding member and original guitarist of Kiss, dies at 74
subhead: Family members said in a statement that they are 'completely devastated and heartbroken' but will cherish his laughter and celebrate the kindness he bestowed upon others. Frehley is the first death among the four founding members, a group that also includes singer-guitarist Paul Stanley, bassist Gene Simmons and drummer Peter Criss.

title: Revealed: Group 78, the secret US task force fighting cybercriminals
subhead: When the FBI presented 'Group 78' to European counterparts in November 2024, some officials were shocked. They expressed particular concerns about the integrity of their investigations.

byline: Allison Zarouri,  Félix Pommier and  Sinead McCausland

title: Five places in and near Paris to savor choux à la crème
subhead: Our selection of bakeries and pastry shops to fully indulge in choux – whether filled with vanilla cream, peanut cream or Japanese cane sugar.

title: First Wap, a discreet cyber-surveillance firm tracking journalists, public figures and corporate executives
subhead: Little known to the public, this long-standing player in the surveillance industry has been selling phone-tracking technology for more than 20 years, including to authoritarian regimes. Among its targets: a journalist investigating the Vatican, an Airbus employee, and Hollywood actor Jared Leto.
